questions.text: A 7 month old baby boy is brought to the clinic by his mother due to “empty scrotum”. On examination, hemiscrotum on right side is not developed and testis is not palpable in the inguinal region. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Diagnostic laparoscopy

 

In a 7-month-old infant with non-palpable undescended testis and absent hemiscrotum, diagnostic laparoscopy is the next step. It helps to locate an intra-abdominal or blind-ending testis and plan further management.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. HCG test dose: Used for cryptorchidism but usually at an older age and when testis is palpable.
 

Option C. Reassurance: Not appropriate without confirming the location of the testis in non-palpable cases.
 

Option D. Inguinal exploration: Considered if testis is palpable in the inguinal canal but not detected on laparoscopy.

choices.text: Aerobic during day time and anaerobic during night time
Anaerobic during day time and aerobic during night time
Anaerobic during day time and night time
Aerobic during day time and night time

questions.text: Which of the following statement is true about Oxidation Pond?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aerobic during day time and anaerobic during night time

 

Oxidation ponds are shallow sewage treatment ponds where natural processes involving sunlight, algae, and bacteria treat wastewater. During the daytime, oxygen is produced by algal photosynthesis, making the pond aerobic. At night, photosynthesis ceases and oxygen is consumed by microorganisms, leading to anaerobic conditions. This cyclic variation is a hallmark of oxidation ponds.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anaerobic during day time and aerobic during night time: This is incorrect because sunlight is essential for algae to produce oxygen; hence, aerobic conditions are always linked to daytime, not nighttime.

 

Option C. Anaerobic during day time and night time: If this were true, the pond would resemble a septic tank, not an oxidation pond. It would fail to utilize algae-mediated oxygenation.

 

Option D. Aerobic during day time and night time: Continuous aerobic conditions are not possible since oxygen is not produced at night, making this option incorrect

questions.text:
A 28-year-old female presents with fever, arthralgia, rash, and fatigue that began 10 days after completing a course of ceftriaxone for a urinary tract infection. Physical examination reveals a diffuse maculopapular rash, tender lymphadenopathy, and mild joint swelling. Laboratory results show:

 

  • Elevated ESR and CRP
  • Decreased C3 and C4 complement levels
  • Mild proteinuria and hematuria
  • No peripheral eosinophilia

 

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Serum sickness

 

  • The patient's symptoms of fever, rash, arthralgia, and fatigue, along with low complement levels (C3 and C4) and recent ceftriaxone use, strongly suggest serum sickness, a Type III hypersensitivity reaction. 
  • Immune complexes formed in response to the drug deposit in tissues, leading to inflammation and complement activation. 
  • The absence of eosinophilia supports this diagnosis, as it differentiates serum sickness from IgE-mediated hypersensitivity (Type I).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis: This presents with renal involvement and low complement levels but typically follows a streptococcal infection and lacks systemic features like rash and arthralgia.

 

Option B. Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE): While SLE can present with similar symptoms, it typically shows autoantibodies such as ANA or anti-dsDNA, which are not mentioned here.

 

Option D. Drug-induced lupus: Drug-induced lupus can present with fever, rash, and arthralgia, but it is more commonly associated with anti-histone antibodies and does not typically involve complement consumption.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serum sickness is a Type III hypersensitivity reaction caused by immune complex deposition and complement activation, often triggered by drugs like ceftriaxone, leading to systemic symptoms such as fever, rash, and arthralgia.

choices.text: The presence of anti-MuSK antibodies excludes the possibility of anti-AChR antibodies in other patients.
Anti-MuSK antibodies are commonly found in patients with weakness confined to ocular muscles.
Anti-MuSK antibodies are present in approximately 40% of anti-AChR antibody-negative patients with generalized myasthenia gravis (MG).
The severity of myasthenia gravis correlates directly with the measured level of anti-AChR antibodies.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with generalized muscle weakness and fatigue that worsens with activity and improves with rest. She also reports diplopia and ptosis. Initial testing reveals a negative serum anti-AChR antibody test. Further investigations reveal the presence of anti-MuSK antibodies. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anti-MuSK antibodies are present in approximately 40% of anti-AChR antibody-negative patients with generalized myasthenia gravis (MG).

 

  • Myasthenia gravis (MG) is an autoimmune disorder that affects the neuromuscular junction (NMJ). 
  • Anti-MuSK (muscle-specific tyrosine kinase) antibodies are present in approximately 40% of patients with generalized MG who are negative for anti-AChR (acetylcholine receptor) antibodies. 
  • These antibodies interfere with the clustering of acetylcholine receptors at the NMJ, contributing to the pathogenesis of MG.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The presence of anti-MuSK antibodies excludes the possibility of anti-AChR antibodies in other patients: While anti-MuSK antibodies are rarely found in anti-AChR-positive patients, their presence does not categorically exclude anti-AChR antibodies in other individuals.

 

Option B. Anti-MuSK antibodies are commonly found in patients with weakness confined to ocular muscles: Anti-MuSK antibodies are typically associated with generalized MG, not with MG limited to ocular muscles.

 

Option D. The severity of myasthenia gravis correlates directly with the measured level of anti-AChR antibodies: The severity of MG does not correlate well with anti-AChR antibody levels across different patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Patients with generalized MG who are negative for anti-AChR antibodies may have anti-MuSK antibodies. 
  • These antibodies play a significant role in the clustering of acetylcholine receptors and are critical for diagnosing antibody-negative MG.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the structural characteristic that differentiates IgG from IgE?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Isotype

 

  • The isotype refers to the differences in the constant region of the heavy chains, which classify immunoglobulins into distinct types (e.g., IgG, IgA, IgE). 
  • IgG and IgE differ in their heavy chain constant regions, which are responsible for their distinct functional properties.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Idiotype: The idiotype defines antigen specificity, not the immunoglobulin class.

 

Option C. Allotypes:  Allotypes involve subtle genetic differences in constant regions but do not define immunoglobulin classes.

 

Option D. Epitope: The epitope refers to the specific part of the antigen recognized by the antibody.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Isotype differences define the immunoglobulin classes, such as IgG and IgE, based on variations in their constant regions.

questions.text: Which of the following tests confirms the identification of Micrococcus species and differentiates it from fermentative gram-positive cocci?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hugh-Leifson oxidation-fermentation test

 

  • Micrococci are oxidative in the Hugh-Leifson oxidation-fermentation test, whereas fermentative gram-positive cocci such as staphylococci show a fermentative pattern.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Catalase test: The catalase test is positive for both Micrococcus and Staphylococcus aureus.

 

Option B. Coagulase test:  The coagulase test differentiates S. aureus from other staphylococci but is not relevant for Micrococcus.

 

Option D. Gram stain morphology: Gram stain morphology (tetrads for Micrococcus) is helpful but not confirmatory.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Hugh-Leifson oxidation-fermentation test differentiates Micrococcus species (oxidative) from fermentative gram-positive cocci like staphylococci.

choices.text: Reduced permeability of the bacterial membrane to antibiotics
Lack of a peptidoglycan-containing cell wall
Efflux pumps that actively expel antibiotics

questions.text: A 21-year-old college student presents with a 2-week history of low-grade fever, fatigue, and a non-productive cough. A chest X-ray shows diffuse peribronchial infiltrates with thickened bronchial markings, but no lobar consolidation. The patient reports no significant improvement with amoxicillin started by his primary care physician a week ago. Which of the following best explains why this organism is resistant to beta-lactam antibiotics?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lack of a peptidoglycan-containing cell wall

 

  • Mycoplasma pneumoniae is a cell wall-deficient organism, which makes it inherently resistant to beta-lactam antibiotics like amoxicillin. 
  • Beta-lactams target the bacterial cell wall synthesis by inhibiting penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs), but since Mycoplasma lacks a cell wall and peptidoglycan, these antibiotics are ineffective.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Production of beta-lactamase: This mechanism is seen in some gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria, but Mycoplasma pneumoniae does not produce beta-lactamase as it does not have a cell wall.

 

Option B. Reduced permeability of the bacterial membrane to antibiotics: While some bacteria have outer membranes that limit drug penetration, Mycoplasma pneumoniae lacks such a membrane and does not rely on this mechanism.

 

Option D. Efflux pumps that actively expel antibiotics: Efflux pumps can confer resistance in some bacteria, but this is not the primary mechanism of resistance in Mycoplasma pneumoniae.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mycoplasma pneumoniae is resistant to beta-lactam antibiotics due to its lack of a peptidoglycan-containing cell wall. 
  • This unique feature necessitates the use of antibiotics that target other bacterial components, such as macrolides or tetracyclines.

choices.text: Oocysts are immediately infective, leading to autoinfection
Sporulation of the oocysts occurs in soil, prolonging environmental exposure
Intracellular trophozoites evade the host immune system through antigenic variation
Sporozoites invade the colonic mucosa, causing extensive tissue destruction

questions.text: A 35-year-old HIV-positive man presents with severe watery diarrhea, abdominal cramping, and weight loss. Kinyoun stain of stool samples is showing cysts measuring 4-6 µm, as in the image below . Which of the following best explains the persistence of symptoms in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oocysts are immediately infective, leading to autoinfection

 

  • In Cryptosporidium infections, oocysts are immediately infective upon excretion and can cause autoinfection, leading to persistent symptoms, especially in immunocompromised individuals like those with HIV.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sporulation of the oocysts occurs in soil, prolonging environmental exposure: This describes Cyclospora and Cystoisospora but not Cryptosporidium.

 

Option C. Intracellular trophozoites evade the host immune system through antigenic variation: Antigenic variation is not a known mechanism in Cryptosporidium infections.

 

Option D. Sporozoites invade the colonic mucosa, causing extensive tissue destruction: Cryptosporidium primarily infects the small intestinal epithelium and causes non-inflammatory diarrhea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cryptosporidium oocysts are immediately infective upon excretion and can cause autoinfection, leading to persistent diarrhea in immunocompromised hosts.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman with diabetic neuropathy pain is started on pregabalin. Which of the following conditions is also an FDA-approved indication for pregabalin?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Spinal cord injury pain

 

  • Pregabalin is FDA-approved for several conditions, including focal seizures, post-herpetic neuralgia, diabetic neuropathy pain, spinal cord injury pain, and fibromyalgia.
  • It works similarly to gabapentin by inhibiting presynaptic calcium channel currents.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Generalized anxiety disorder: Pregabalin has been used off-label for generalized anxiety disorder in some regions but is not an FDA-approved indication.

 

Option C. Cluster headache prophylaxis: Pregabalin is not used for headache prophylaxis.

 

Option D. Tension headache: Pregabalin is not indicated for treating tension headaches.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pregabalin is approved for treating neuropathic pain conditions, including diabetic neuropathy, post-herpetic neuralgia, and spinal cord injury pain, in addition to fibromyalgia.

choices.text: Keratinized epithelium, submucosa, and minor salivary glands
Keratinized epithelium, absent submucosa, and no salivary glands
Non-keratinized epithelium, submucosa, and minor salivary glands
Non-keratinized epithelium, absent submucosa, and minor salivary glands

questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes the features of the hard palate?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Keratinized epithelium, submucosa, and minor salivary glands

 

  • The hard palate is part of the oral cavity’s masticatory mucosa and is covered by keratinized stratified squamous epithelium. 
  • The epithelium provides resistance to friction during mastication. The hard palate also contains a submucosa, which varies in thickness and supports the epithelium. 
  • This submucosa contains minor salivary glands, which secrete mucus to aid in lubrication.

 

Key features of the hard palate:

 

  • Epithelium: Keratinized stratified squamous epithelium.
  • Submucosa: Present, containing connective tissue and minor salivary glands.
  • Function: Provides a firm surface for mastication and separates the oral and nasal cavities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The hard palate is covered by keratinized stratified squamous epithelium with an underlying submucosa containing minor salivary glands. This structure supports the masticatory function of the oral cavity.

choices.text: Ventral rami of S1 and S2

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with chronic hip pain and difficulty with external rotation of the thigh. Neurological testing suggests an injury affecting the inferior gemellus muscle. Which nerve is responsible for innervating this muscle?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nerve to quadratus femoris

 

  • The inferior gemellus muscle is one of the lateral rotators of the hip joint. 
  • It functions alongside the quadratus femoris and is innervated by the nerve to quadratus femoris (L4, L5, S1). 
  • This nerve supplies both the quadratus femoris and the inferior gemellus muscles.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nerve to obturator internus: This nerve supplies the obturator internus and superior gemellus muscles, not the inferior gemellus.

 

Option C. Nerve to obturator externus: The obturator externus is innervated by the posterior branch of the obturator nerve (L2–L4), not the nerve to quadratus femoris.

 

Option D. Ventral rami of S1 and S2: The ventral rami of S1 and S2 contribute to the nerve to piriformis and the sciatic nerve, but they do not innervate the inferior gemellus directly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The inferior gemellus muscle is innervated by the nerve to quadratus femoris (L4, L5, S1). 
  • Recognizing the innervation of the muscles involved in hip rotation helps in localizing neuromuscular injuries during clinical assessment.

questions.text: Which of the following ligaments links the medial cuneiform bone to the base of the second metatarsal bone?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lisfranc ligament

 

  • The Lisfranc ligament is a strong ligament that connects the medial cuneiform to the base of the second metatarsal bone and is crucial for the stability of the midfoot.
  • An injury to this ligament, commonly known as a Lisfranc injury, can lead to instability and misalignment of the tarsometatarsal joint, often seen in trauma or sports-related injuries. 
  • The ligament stabilizes the midfoot by holding the bones in place and preventing splaying of the metatarsals.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spring ligament: Also known as the calcaneonavicular ligament, it provides support to the medial longitudinal arch of the foot but does not connect the cuneiform to the metatarsal.

 

Option B. Chopart ligament: This refers to ligaments associated with the Chopart joint complex (talonavicular and calcaneocuboid joints), not the tarsometatarsal joint.

 

Option C. Deltoid ligament: This is a strong, triangular ligament complex that stabilizes the medial aspect of the ankle, not the midfoot.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Lisfranc ligament links the medial cuneiform to the base of the second metatarsal and is vital for midfoot stability. 
  • Lisfranc injuries should be promptly diagnosed to avoid long-term complications such as chronic pain and midfoot instability.

questions.text: The unequal distribution of ions across the plasma membrane, described by the Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium, is primarily due to the presence of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Intracellular proteins

 

  • The Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium describes the distribution of ions across a semipermeable membrane in the presence of impermeant charged molecules, such as intracellular proteins. 
  • These negatively charged proteins cannot cross the cell membrane, causing an unequal distribution of permeant ions (e.g., sodium, potassium, chloride) to maintain electrochemical balance. 
  • This leads to a higher concentration of cations (like sodium) outside the cell and anions (like chloride) inside the cell, contributing to osmotic pressure regulation and ion balance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bicarbonate ion: Bicarbonate primarily buffers the extracellular space and plays a minimal role in the intracellular ion distribution or the Gibbs-Donnan effect.

 

Option B. Calcium ion: Calcium ions are mainly found extracellularly and play a role in signaling, but they are not involved in the establishment of the Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium.

 

Option C. Sodium: Sodium (Na⁺) is a major extracellular cation and contributes to maintaining membrane potential through the sodium-potassium pump. However, its distribution across the membrane is actively maintained by ATP-dependent transport rather than being a direct result of the Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium is maintained by the presence of impermeant negatively charged intracellular proteins that create an unequal distribution of ions across the membrane to balance the electrochemical gradient.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with excessive weight gain and an insatiable appetite despite eating regular meals. Damage to which part of the hypothalamus is most likely causing his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ventromedial Nucleus

 

  • The ventromedial nucleus (VMN) of the hypothalamus is the "satiety center" that signals fullness and inhibits appetite. 
  • Damage to this region impairs the ability to regulate food intake, leading to hyperphagia (excessive hunger) and weight gain. 
  • Lesions in this nucleus are associated with obesity due to the absence of inhibitory signals that control feeding behavior.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Paraventricular Nucleus: Primarily involved in regulating water balance, stress response, and food intake by releasing hormones like oxytocin and vasopressin. While it has a minor role in appetite regulation, it is not the primary satiety center.

 

Option C. Arcuate Nucleus: The arcuate nucleus integrates signals from peripheral hormones such as leptin, ghrelin, and insulin to regulate hunger and satiety. However, it modulates appetite rather than being the primary satiety center like the ventromedial nucleus.

 

Option D. Suprachiasmatic Nucleus: This nucleus regulates circadian rhythms, including the sleep-wake cycle, but does not play a direct role in appetite regulation or weight control.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The ventromedial nucleus of the hypothalamus acts as the satiety center, and damage to this region leads to hyperphagia and weight gain.

questions.text: Which skeletal muscle fibers are classified as Fast Oxidative-Glycolytic (FOG) fibers, known for their balance between speed and endurance?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Type IIA

 

  • Type IIA muscle fibers are fast oxidative-glycolytic (FOG) fibers. They possess both aerobic and anaerobic metabolic properties, making them efficient at producing ATP through both oxidative phosphorylation and glycolysis. 
  • These fibers are intermediate in terms of contraction speed and fatigue resistance, providing a balance between strength and endurance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type I: These are slow-twitch oxidative fibers, highly fatigue-resistant, with a focus on endurance rather than speed. They primarily use aerobic metabolism.

 

Option C. Type IIB: These are fast glycolytic fibers, specialized for short bursts of power and speed but fatigue quickly due to reliance on anaerobic metabolism.

 

Option D. Type IIC: These fibers are transitional fibers that appear during muscle regeneration and are not a standard classification for mature muscle fibers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Type IIA fibers (fast oxidative-glycolytic) are characterized by a balance between contraction speed and endurance, using both aerobic and anaerobic metabolic pathways.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man presents with severe shortness of breath. Echocardiography reveals mitral stenosis and left atrial hypertrophy. During surgery, vegetations are found on the mitral valve and are excised. The histopathological examination of the excised vegetations is shown in the image below. Based on the histopathological findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rheumatic heart disease

 

  • The histopathological image shows Aschoff bodies, which are characteristic of rheumatic heart disease (RHD). 
  • Aschoff bodies are granulomatous structures found in the myocardium during acute rheumatic fever. 
  • Rheumatic heart disease develops as a sequela of acute rheumatic fever, typically following an infection with group A Streptococcus. 
  • This condition leads to chronic inflammation, fibrosis, and valvular deformity, most commonly affecting the mitral valve. 
  • The presence of vegetations on the mitral valve in a patient with mitral stenosis strongly suggests rheumatic valvular disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nonbacterial thrombotic endocarditis (NBTE): Incorrect. NBTE is associated with hypercoagulable states and malignancies, leading to the formation of sterile vegetations on heart valves. These vegetations are typically non-inflammatory and lack the granulomatous changes seen in Aschoff bodies.

 

Option C. Libman-Sacks endocarditis: Incorrect. Libman-Sacks endocarditis is associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and involves the formation of sterile vegetations on heart valves, particularly the mitral and aortic valves. However, these vegetations are not associated with Aschoff bodies or the granulomatous changes seen in rheumatic heart disease.

 

Option D. Cardiac amyloidosis: Incorrect. Cardiac amyloidosis is characterized by the deposition of amyloid in the myocardium, leading to restrictive cardiomyopathy. It does not present with valvular vegetations or granulomatous inflammation like Aschoff bodies, which are specific to rheumatic heart disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Rheumatic heart disease (RHD) is a chronic consequence of acute rheumatic fever, characterized by valvular damage and granulomatous changes such as Aschoff bodies. 
  • It most frequently affects the mitral valve, leading to mitral stenosis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of recurrent epistaxis and easy bruising. Laboratory tests show a prolonged bleeding time but normal platelet count. A peripheral blood smear shows large platelets. A platelet aggregation study reveals an abnormal response to ristocetin but a normal response to ADP and collagen. Which of the following deficiencies is most likely causing her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glycoprotein Ib/IX

 

  • Bernard-Soulier syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a deficiency of glycoprotein (Gp) Ib/IX, which is necessary for platelet adhesion to von Willebrand factor (vWF) at sites of endothelial injury. 
  • Without Gp Ib/IX, platelets cannot properly bind to the subendothelial vWF, leading to impaired platelet plug formation and prolonged bleeding time.
  • A hallmark finding is large platelets on a peripheral smear due to dysfunctional platelet production.
  • The abnormal ristocetin-induced aggregation test (which depends on Gp Ib/IX binding to vWF) further supports the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glycoprotein IIb/IIIa: This glycoprotein complex is involved in platelet-platelet aggregation by binding fibrinogen. Its deficiency leads to Glanzmann thrombasthenia, which presents with abnormal aggregation to ADP, collagen, and thrombin, but normal ristocetin aggregation.

 

Option C. Von Willebrand factor (vWF): Deficiency or dysfunction of vWF causes von Willebrand disease, characterized by defective platelet adhesion. Unlike Bernard-Soulier syndrome, von Willebrand disease presents with normal platelet size and often involves reduced levels of factor VIII (since vWF stabilizes factor VIII).

 

Option D. Factor VIII: Deficiency of factor VIII results in hemophilia A, which presents with normal bleeding time (platelet function is intact) but prolonged partial thromboplastin time (PTT) due to impaired intrinsic coagulation. Hemarthrosis and deep tissue bleeding are common presentations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Bernard-Soulier syndrome is caused by a deficiency of glycoprotein Ib/IX, which plays a critical role in platelet adhesion to von Willebrand factor. 
  • It is characterized by large platelets, prolonged bleeding time, and defective platelet aggregation in response to ristocetin.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with a history of recurrent epigastric pain and dyspepsia undergoes an upper GI endoscopy, revealing gastric mucosal inflammation with a possible ulcer. A biopsy is taken, and the image shows the result of a special stain used to identify the organism involved. Which of the following stains is most likely depicted in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Warthin-Starry silver stain

 

  • The Warthin-Starry stain is a silver-based stain commonly used to detect Helicobacter pylori, a spiral-shaped, Gram-negative bacterium associated with gastritis and peptic ulcer disease.
  • In this stain, the H. pylori appear as dark, spiral-shaped structures against the background of the gastric epithelial lining, as shown in the image.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Masson-Fontana stain: This stain is used to detect melanin and other substances, such as argentaffin granules, and is not specific for bacterial organisms.

 

Option B. Periodic Acid Schiff (PAS) stain: PAS stain highlights glycoproteins, mucin, and fungal elements, which appear magenta. It is not used for identifying H. pylori.

 

Option C. Gomori's methenamine silver stain: This is primarily used for fungal organisms and is especially useful for staining Pneumocystis jirovecii cysts. It is not typically used for H. pylori detection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Warthin-Starry stain is a silver stain used to detect H. pylori, which appears as spiral-shaped, dark-staining bacteria. 
  • This stain is crucial in diagnosing H. pylori-related gastritis and peptic ulcer disease.

questions.text: A 45-year-old gardener presents to the clinic with a 2-week history of painless nodular lesions on his left forearm. He recalls pricking his hand on a thorn while trimming rose bushes 3 weeks ago. The lesions began as a small papule on his hand and have since spread proximally along the forearm in a linear pattern. He denies fever, chills, or systemic symptoms. The image of the lesion is shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Itraconazole

 

  • The patient’s history of gardening, traumatic inoculation, and the presence of painless nodular lesions following a lymphatic distribution is characteristic of sporotrichosis, caused by Sporothrix schenckii. 
  • Itraconazole, an oral antifungal, is the treatment of choice for cutaneous and lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Doxycycline: Doxycycline is effective against bacterial infections and some rickettsial diseases but is not effective for fungal infections like sporotrichosis.

 

Option C. Amphotericin B: Amphotericin B is reserved for severe systemic fungal infections, such as disseminated sporotrichosis, but is not necessary for localized lymphocutaneous cases.

 

Option D. Flucloxacillin: Flucloxacillin is an antibiotic used to treat bacterial infections like cellulitis or abscesses caused by Staphylococcus aureus. It is not effective against fungal infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sporotrichosis is a subcutaneous fungal infection often associated with traumatic inoculation during gardening. 
  • The typical presentation includes nodular lesions spreading along lymphatics, and itraconazole is the first-line treatment for lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis.

questions.text: What triage category is a degloving injury going to be tagged?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Yellow

 

 

  • The yellow category in triage indicates urgent care is required, but the patient is likely to survive if treatment is provided within hours.
  • A degloving injury, which involves severe soft tissue loss and risk of infection, fits this category.
  • Immediate attention is not critical for survival, but delayed care can lead to complications such as infection, tissue necrosis, or systemic involvement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Red: This category is reserved for patients who are in immediate need of treatment to survive, such as those with tension pneumothorax, massive hemorrhage, or other life-threatening injuries. Degloving injuries, while severe, are not usually life-threatening in the immediate term.

 

Option C. Green: This category is for non-urgent cases, such as minor lacerations or simple fractures. Degloving injuries are much more severe and require urgent medical intervention.

 

Option D. Black: This category is for patients who are unsalvageable, such as those with severe brain damage or injuries incompatible with life. Degloving injuries do not fall into this category as the prognosis is good with timely intervention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A degloving injury is triaged as yellow because it is an urgent condition that requires medical treatment within hours but is not immediately life-threatening. 
  • Triage categories prioritize resource allocation during mass casualty events.

questions.text: Calculate the GCS-P score of a patient brought into the ER with history of fall from a motorcycle. He is just making incomprehensible sounds, has a completely flexed posture and only opens his eyes to knuckle pressure. On examination, right pupil is unreactive to light:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 6

 

To calculate the GCS-P (Glasgow Coma Scale-Pupils) score for the patient, we will assess the eye, verbal, and motor responses, and then adjust for pupil reactivity.

 

  1. Eye response: The patient opens eyes to knuckle pressure (pain), which scores a 2.
  2. Verbal response: The patient is making incomprehensible sounds, which scores a 2.
  3. Motor response: The patient has a completely flexed posture, which is consistent with decorticate posturing, which scores a 3.

 

Adding these together:

 

Eye Response + Verbal Response + Motor Response=2+2+3=7

 

Now, for the pupillary response:

 

One pupil is unreactive to light, which subtracts 1 from the GCS score.

 

GCS Score−Pupillary Score=7−1=6

 

The final GCS-P score is 6.

 

The correct answer is B. 6.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The Glasgow Coma Scale-Pupils (GCS-P) is an extension of the GCS that includes the assessment of pupillary light response. 
  • It is used to evaluate the severity of brain injuries. 
  • The GCS-P score is derived by subtracting the pupillary score from the GCS score, providing a more comprehensive assessment of the patient's neurological status.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency room with fever, chest pain, and difficulty breathing. A chest X-ray reveals lobar pneumonia. Blood cultures show gram-positive, lancet-shaped diplococci. Colonies on blood agar incubated for 24 hours show a characteristic pattern as shown below. Which of the following is responsible for this appearance?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Autolysin

 

  • Autolysin is an amidase enzyme produced by Streptococcus pneumoniae that cleaves peptidoglycan, leading to the autolysis of cells. 
  • This enzymatic activity results in the central umbonation and concentric rings of colonies, commonly described as the "draughtsman appearance" or "carrom coin appearance."

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lipoteichoic acid: Lipoteichoic acid is a component of gram-positive cell walls but does not cause this colony morphology.

 

Option C. Capsule polysaccharides: Capsule polysaccharides are responsible for virulence and resistance to phagocytosis but do not influence colony morphology.

 

Option D. Pneumolysin: Pneumolysin is a cytotoxin that contributes to tissue damage but does not influence colony appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The "draughtsman appearance" of Streptococcus pneumoniae colonies is due to autolysin, an enzyme responsible for peptidoglycan degradation and bile solubility.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male presents with a fluctuant mass in the jaw region and purulent discharge from multiple sinuses. The culture shows the colonies displayed in the given image below. Which of the following is a key feature of the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gram-positive obligate anaerobe

 

  • Actinomyces species are Gram-positive obligate anaerobes that are part of the normal oral and gastrointestinal flora, is characterized by the formation of molar tooth colonies on culture. 
  • They cause chronic granulomatous infections, particularly in immunocompromised hosts or following mucosal injury.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gram-negative obligate anaerobe: Incorrect; Actinomyces are Gram-positive.

 

Option B. Gram-positive facultative anaerobe: Incorrect; Actinomyces are obligate anaerobes.

 

Option D. Acid-fast bacterium: Acid-fast staining identifies Mycobacterium species, not Actinomyces.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Actinomyces species are Gram-positive obligate anaerobes associated with chronic granulomatous infections, presenting with molar tooth colonies on culture.

choices.text: G to A mutation in the Pre-C region
Stop codon mutation in the P region

questions.text: A 34-year-old patient with chronic hepatitis B infection is found to have undetectable levels of HBeAg despite active viral replication. Which mutation in the hepatitis B virus genome is most likely responsible for this finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) G to A mutation in the Pre-C region

 

  • Pre-core mutants of hepatitis B virus are unable to synthesize HBeAg due to a G to A mutation at the 28th amino acid in the Pre-C region. 
  • This mutation introduces a stop codon, preventing the synthesis of HBeAg. 
  • These mutants can still produce HBcAg and replicate actively, leading to high viral loads despite the absence of HBeAg.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mutation in the S region: This region codes for HBsAg, which is unrelated to the production of HBeAg.

 

Option B. Mutation in the C region: The C region codes for HBcAg, not HBeAg, and is not affected in Pre-core mutants.

 

Option D. Stop codon mutation in the P region: The P region codes for viral polymerase and is unrelated to HBeAg synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Pre-core mutants of hepatitis B virus have a G to A mutation in the Pre-C region, resulting in a stop codon that prevents HBeAg synthesis while allowing active viral replication.

questions.text: Match the Following:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1-C, 2-A, 3-D, 4-B

 

1-C. Ductus Arteriosus → Ligamentum Arteriosum: The ductus arteriosus connects the pulmonary artery to the aorta in fetal circulation and closes to form the ligamentum arteriosum after birth.

 

2-A. Umbilical vein → Ligamentum teres hepatis: During fetal development, the umbilical vein plays a crucial role in transporting oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetal heart. After birth, the umbilical vein becomes redundant due to the cessation of placental circulation and undergoes transformation. This remnant becomes the ligamentum teres hepatis (commonly known as the round ligament of the liver).

 

3-D. Foramen Ovale → Fossa Ovalis: The foramen ovale allows blood to flow between the right and left atria in the fetus, bypassing the lungs. After birth, it closes to form the fossa ovalis.

 

4-B. Allantois → Urachus → Median Umbilical Ligament: The allantois initially functions in waste collection and gas exchange. After birth, it becomes the urachus and then the median umbilical ligament.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with osteoporosis is started on risedronate to reduce her risk of fractures. The medication acts by inhibiting an enzyme involved in cholesterol biosynthesis, disrupting osteoclast function. Which of the following enzymes is directly inhibited by risedronate?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Farnesyl pyrophosphate synthase (FPPS)

 

  • Risedronate is a bisphosphonate that inhibits farnesyl pyrophosphate synthase (FPPS), a key enzyme in the mevalonate pathway. 
  • FPPS catalyzes the synthesis of farnesyl pyrophosphate, a precursor for isoprenoid lipids crucial for osteoclast function. 
  • By inhibiting this enzyme, risedronate disrupts osteoclast activity, reducing bone resorption and increasing bone density
  • This mechanism makes bisphosphonates like risedronate highly effective in treating osteoporosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HMG-CoA reductase: Statins inhibit this enzyme, reducing cholesterol synthesis. Risedronate does not target HMG-CoA reductase.

 

Option C. Squalene synthase: This enzyme is involved later in cholesterol synthesis but is not inhibited by risedronate.

 

Option D. Geranylgeranyl transferase: This enzyme is responsible for post-translational prenylation of proteins but is not directly inhibited by risedronate.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Risedronate inhibits farnesyl pyrophosphate synthase in the mevalonate pathway, impairing osteoclast function and reducing bone resorption.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman is diagnosed with persistent atrial fibrillation. She is prescribed an antiarrhythmic drug that selectively prolongs the action potential by blocking delayed rectifier potassium channels (IKr) during Phase 3. The drug has no significant effects on sodium or calcium channels, nor does it act on beta-adrenergic receptors. Which of the following drugs was most likely prescribed to her?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dofetilide

 

  • Dofetilide is a pure Class III antiarrhythmic agent that acts specifically by blocking the delayed rectifier potassium channels (IKr) during Phase 3 of the cardiac action potential. 
  • This results in prolonged repolarization and an increased duration of the action potential. 
  • Unlike other Class III agents like amiodarone, dofetilide does not have additional effects on sodium, calcium, or adrenergic receptors. 
  • It is specifically indicated for the maintenance of sinus rhythm in patients with atrial fibrillation or flutter.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amiodarone: While it is a Class III antiarrhythmic agent, it has multiple effects, including sodium channel blockade, beta-adrenergic blockade, and calcium channel inhibition, making it a non-pure action potential-prolonging drug.

 

Option B. Procainamide: This is a Class IA antiarrhythmic agent that primarily blocks sodium channels and prolongs the action potential by slowing Phase 0 depolarization. It is not a pure potassium channel blocker.

 

Option D. Phenytoin: A Class IB antiarrhythmic agent, phenytoin shortens the action potential duration by accelerating repolarization. It does not block potassium channels in the same way as Class III agents.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Dofetilide is a pure Class III antiarrhythmic drug that prolongs the action potential by selectively blocking the delayed rectifier potassium channels (IKr) during Phase 3 of the cardiac action potential. 
  • It does not have effects on sodium or calcium channels or adrenergic receptors, distinguishing it from other Class III agents.

questions.text: A drug classified as an inverse agonist at benzodiazepine receptors is likely to produce which of the following effects?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increased anxiety and seizures

 

  • Inverse agonists at benzodiazepine receptors, such as beta-carbolines, reduce receptor activity below baseline, opposing the effects of benzodiazepine agonists. 
  • This leads to increased neuronal excitability, manifesting as heightened anxiety, restlessness, and seizures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sedation and anxiolysis: Sedation and anxiolysis are effects of agonists at benzodiazepine receptors, not inverse agonists.

 

Option C. Reduction of dopamine activity: Dopamine activity is not directly affected by benzodiazepine receptor modulation.

 

Option D. Partial dopamine receptor blockade: Partial dopamine receptor blockade is unrelated to benzodiazepine receptor effects.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Inverse agonists reduce receptor activity below baseline, leading to excitatory effects like anxiety and seizures at benzodiazepine receptors.

choices.text: Alteration of DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman is diagnosed with a urinary tract infection caused by Escherichia coli resistant to ciprofloxacin. What is the most likely mechanism of resistance in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alteration of DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV

 

  • Resistance to ciprofloxacin and other fluoroquinolones often involves mutations in DNA gyrase or topoisomerase IV, the enzymes targeted by this drug. 
  • These mutations reduce the drug's binding affinity, decreasing its efficacy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enzymatic inactivation of ciprofloxacin: Incorrect because enzymatic inactivation of fluoroquinolones is uncommon.

 

Option C. Development of beta-lactamase enzymes: Incorrect as beta-lactamases are not involved in fluoroquinolone resistance.

 

Option D. Alteration of cell membrane permeability: Incorrect because reduced permeability is not the primary mechanism for ciprofloxacin resistance.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Ciprofloxacin resistance typically arises from mutations in DNA gyrase or topoisomerase IV, the drug’s primary targets.

choices.text: Decreased alkaline phosphatase activity in osteoblasts
Increased expression of RANKL in osteoblasts
Enhanced formation of secondary ossification centers

questions.text: A research team has created a knocked-out mouse model in which the gene for cathepsin K, a proteolytic enzyme in osteoclasts, is inactivated. Which of the following changes is most likely observed in this model?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increased hydroxyapatite levels in bone

 

  • Cathepsin K is essential for the breakdown of the organic matrix of bone, particularly collagen. 
  • Its absence impairs bone resorption, leading to the accumulation of hydroxyapatite.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Decreased alkaline phosphatase activity in osteoblasts: Osteoblast activity remains unaffected as the gene is specific to osteoclasts.

 

Option C. Increased expression of RANKL in osteoblasts: RANKL expression is not directly linked to cathepsin K activity.

 

Option D. Enhanced formation of secondary ossification centers: This process is unrelated to cathepsin K or osteoclast function.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • The absence of cathepsin K in osteoclasts impairs bone resorption, leading to accumulation of hydroxyapatite.

choices.text: Administration of a high-dose angiotensin II receptor blocker
Dehydration causing increased plasma protein concentration
Sympathetic activation leading to afferent arteriole constriction
Ureteral obstruction from a pelvic tumor

questions.text: In which of the following scenarios would GFR decrease, renal plasma flow remains constant, and filtration fraction decrease?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ureteral obstruction from a pelvic tumor

 

Ureteral obstruction from a pelvic tumor leads to an increase in backpressure within the renal tubules. This increased pressure is transmitted backward into the glomerulus, reducing glomerular filtration rate (GFR). Renal plasma flow (RPF) typically remains constant in this situation, as the obstruction does not directly affect the blood flow to the kidneys. However, due to the decrease in GFR while RPF remains unchanged, the filtration fraction (FF) (which is the ratio of GFR to RPF) decreases.

 

  • GFR decreases because of the increased resistance to filtration caused by the backpressure in the renal tubules.
  • RPF remains constant as the obstruction does not interfere with blood flow to the kidneys.
  • FF decreases because GFR decreases while RPF remains constant, leading to a reduction in the ratio.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Administration of a high-dose angiotensin II receptor blocker: Incorrect. Angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs) primarily work by dilating the efferent arteriole, which reduces glomerular pressure and decreases GFR. However, this also leads to a reduction in renal plasma flow (RPF), making the filtration fraction hard to maintain in the same manner. RPF does not remain constant, and this scenario doesn't match the question's description.

 

Option B. Dehydration causing increased plasma protein concentration: Incorrect. Dehydration increases plasma protein concentration, which raises the oncotic pressure in the glomerulus and reduces GFR. However, renal plasma flow would also decrease in dehydration due to hypovolemia (reduced circulating volume), making it not match the description where RPF remains constant. Additionally, the filtration fraction would likely increase due to a larger decrease in RPF than in GFR, not decrease.

 

Option C. Sympathetic activation leading to afferent arteriole constriction: Incorrect. Sympathetic activation causes vasoconstriction of the afferent arteriole, which reduces renal plasma flow (RPF) and GFR. The filtration fraction would not remain constant because both GFR and RPF would decrease in this situation. Hence, this scenario does not fit the question's parameters where RPF is constant.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

  • PG: Glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure
  • πG: Glomerular capillary colloid osmotic pressure
  • PB: Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure

questions.text: The abnormal pink curve in the flow-volume loop is least likely to be associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency

 

  • Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency leads to emphysema, an obstructive disease, and is unlikely to produce a restrictive flow-volume loop.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sarcoidosis: Sarcoidosis can cause restrictive lung disease due to granuloma formation.

 

Option B. Interstitial lung disease: Interstitial lung disease results in restrictive patterns with reduced lung compliance.

 

Option C. Obesity hypoventilation syndrome: Obesity hypoventilation syndrome causes a restrictive pattern due to mechanical limitations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Restrictive patterns on flow-volume loops are not characteristic of obstructive diseases like alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency.

choices.text: CGG repeat expansion on the FMR1 gene

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presents with progressive ataxia, kyphoscoliosis, and bilateral foot deformities. Neurological examination reveals diminished proprioception and absent reflexes in the lower extremities. An echocardiogram shows left ventricular hypertrophy. Which genetic abnormality is most likely responsible for her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) GAA repeat expansion on chromosome 9q13

 

  • The clinical presentation of Friedrich's ataxia includes ataxia, kyphoscoliosis, foot deformities (e.g., pes cavus), diminished proprioception, and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. 
  • This is caused by a GAA trinucleotide repeat expansion in the frataxin gene on chromosome 9q13.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CAG repeat expansion on chromosome 4: This is characteristic of Huntington's disease, which involves chorea and cognitive decline.

 

Option C. CTG repeat expansion on chromosome 19: This is associated with myotonic dystrophy, characterized by muscle weakness and myotonia.

 

Option D. CGG repeat expansion on the FMR1 gene: This is linked to fragile X syndrome, causing intellectual disability.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Friedrich's ataxia is caused by a GAA trinucleotide repeat expansion in the frataxin gene on chromosome 9q13.

choices.text: Direct bacterial invasion of adrenal cortical cells

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl presents with fever, widespread purpura, and hypotension. Despite aggressive treatment, she dies shortly after admission. An adrenal biopsy is obtained postmortem and reveals the following findings. Which of the following mechanisms is primarily responsible for the observed histological changes?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Endotoxin-mediated endothelial damage

 

  • The pathogenesis of Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome involves endotoxin-mediated endothelial damage, leading to microvascular injury, hemorrhage, and necrosis of the adrenal glands. 

 

 

The histology shows extensive hemorrhage with cortical necrosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Direct bacterial invasion of adrenal cortical cells: Rarely occurs; bacterial products like endotoxins mediate the damage.

 

Option C. Autoimmune destruction of adrenal tissue: This is the mechanism in autoimmune adrenalitis, not relevant here.

 

Option D. Ischemic necrosis due to thrombosis: While DIC is present, the primary injury is endothelial damage caused by microbial toxins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome results from endotoxin-mediated endothelial damage, leading to adrenal hemorrhage and acute adrenal insufficiency.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presents with chronic sinusitis and productive cough. A nasal biopsy reveals ciliated cell degeneration, characterized by shedding and loss of cilia. Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acute viral respiratory infection

 

  • Ciliocytophthoria refers to the degeneration of ciliated cells seen in acute viral infections, such as the common cold or influenza. 
  • This phenomenon involves loss of cilia, leading to impaired mucociliary clearance and transient susceptibility to secondary infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Kartagener syndrome: Characterized by ciliary immotility due to structural defects, not degeneration.

 

Option C. Cystic fibrosis: Involves normal ciliary structure but thick mucus impairs clearance.

 

Option D. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease: Associated with epithelial metaplasia and mucus hypersecretion, not ciliated cell degeneration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ciliocytophthoria occurs in acute viral respiratory infections, resulting in ciliated cell degeneration and impaired clearance.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with progressive dyspnea, fatigue, and lower extremity edema. An echocardiogram reveals global hypokinesis and a dilated left ventricle with a reduced ejection fraction of 25%. A myocardial biopsy reveals the histopathology image given below. Which of the following genetic abnormalities is most likely responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mutation in the TTN gene

 

  • The TTN gene, which encodes titin, is commonly mutated in dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM). 
  • Truncating mutations lead to a shortened protein, impairing sarcomeric function. 
  • Histologically, myocytes with bizarre, "ninja-star"-like nuclei are characteristic of DCM.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mutation in the FBN1 gene: Associated with Marfan syndrome, leading to aortic aneurysms, not DCM.

 

Option C. Mutation in the LMNA gene: Linked to familial DCM with conduction system abnormalities but less common than TTN mutations.

 

Option D. Mutation in the MYH7 gene: Associated with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy rather than DCM.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mutations in the TTN gene are the most common genetic cause of dilated cardiomyopathy and are associated with histological findings like bizarre nuclei in myocytes.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents with a rapidly growing bladder tumor. Genetic analysis will reveal:
questions.solution: Ans. B) Activation of HRAS

questions.text: An illustration of two graphs (A and B) that represent the affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen is shown. Which of the following best explains a shift from A to B?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Increased body temperature

questions.text: Which of the following monoclonal antibodies is least likely to act on the HER1 (EGFR) receptor?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Pertuzumab

questions.text: Two days after undergoing uncomplicated total knee replacement, a 55-year-old man develops increasing anxiety, agitation, hand tremor, and nausea. He told the nurse he saw a bear in his room. His pain has been controlled with intravenous morphine. He has a history of advanced liver disease. He drinks 7 cans of beer daily. He is diaphoretic. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 118/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 146/92 mm Hg. Administration of which of the following drugs is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Lorazepam

choices.text: Corrected transposition of the great vessels
Dynamic obstruction of the left ventricular outflow tract

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the OPD due to fatigue when playing basketball. The patient finds it difficult to play for a long time and to compete with his peers. He has had no shortness of breath, chest pain, or palpitations.  On physical examination, the patient has a soft mid-systolic murmur best heard at the left upper sternal border. Heart sounds are shown below.  Which of the following is the most likely cause of the observed findings?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Left-to-right intracardiac shunting

choices.text: Angular gyrus of the parietal lobe

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with a history of diabetes and hypertension presents with complaints of difficulty in reading, however faces no difficulty while writing. Which of the following regions of his brain may be affected?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Splenium of corpus callosum

choices.text: Left Superior middle cerebral artery stroke
Left Inferior middle cerebral artery stroke

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset weakness on the right side of his body and difficulty speaking, which began one hour ago while he was at work. He has a history of secondary progressive multiple sclerosis diagnosed 30 years ago with multiple exacerbations, as well as hypertension and hyperlipidemia. His speech is limited to 1–2 words with great effort. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for the patient’s current presentation?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Left Superior middle cerebral artery stroke

questions.text: The enteric nervous plexus is present at:
questions.solution: Ans. B) 2, 3

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrectly matched with respect to the porphyria and the enzyme involved?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Congenital erythropoietic porphyria - Coproporphyrinogen oxidase

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding enzymes are true: 

 

  1. ΔGf is lowered 
  2. Stability of transition state is reduced
  3. It depends upon complementarity of active site of enzyme and substrate
  4. Activation energy is decreased
questions.solution: Ans. C) 3,4

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with profuse watery diarrhea for the past 3 days, accompanied by lower abdominal pain and mild fever. She was hospitalized 2 weeks ago for pneumonia and treated with intravenous ceftriaxone and oral clarithromycin. Her medical history includes hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Her abdomen is mildly tender to palpation without rebound or guarding. Colonoscopy image is shown below. Which of the following is the treatment of choice for the same?

questions.text: A 21-year-old female college student with a history of anxiety is brought to the physician for evaluation of fatigue for the past 6 months. questions.text: The criteria for early renal graft dysfunction includes:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rise in serum creatinine of >10% baseline

 

  • Early graft dysfunction is defined by a rise in serum creatinine >10% from baseline in the immediate post-transplant period.
  • It reflects impaired graft function and may require further evaluation for rejection, obstruction, or vascular compromise.
  • Absolute creatinine changes (μmol/L) are less reliable than percentage change from baseline in this context.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rise in serum creatinine of >15% baseline: Incorrect. too high a threshold, may delay diagnosis of early dysfunction.

 

Option C. Rise in serum creatinine of >10 μmol/L: Incorrect. absolute value insufficient, does not account for baseline.

 

Option D. Rise in serum creatinine of >15 μmol/L: Incorrect. same as above, percentage change is standard.

questions.text: A young female presents with pain in lower abdomen and vomiting in the ER. Clinical examination reveals a swelling, lateral and below the pubic tubercle. X-ray is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Strangulated femoral hernia

 

The clinical scenario and X-ray findings indicate a femoral hernia, which typically presents as a swelling below and lateral to the pubic tubercle. Associated pain, vomiting, and features of intestinal obstruction point toward strangulation, requiring urgent intervention.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Adhesions: Common cause of intestinal obstruction, but would not present as a groin swelling below the pubic tubercle.
 

Option B. Strangulated inguinal hernia: Swelling would be above and medial to the pubic tubercle, differing from the femoral hernia location.
 

Option D. Direct hernia: Occurs due to weakness in the abdominal wall, presenting as a swelling above the pubic tubercle, not below and lateral.

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements

 

  1. Liposarcoma is the most common retroperitoneal tumor.
  2. M3 midline hernia refers to epigastric hernia 
  3. A mesenteric cyst shows mobility perpendicular to line of mesenteric attachment.
  4. Colon cancer risk can be decreased by metformin
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 3, 4

 

Statement 1. Liposarcoma is the most common retroperitoneal tumor: Correct. Liposarcoma is the most frequent primary malignant retroperitoneal soft tissue tumor, followed by leiomyosarcoma.

 

Statement 3. A mesenteric cyst shows mobility perpendicular to line of mesenteric attachment: Correct. Mesenteric cysts move freely at right angles to the root of mesentery, but not parallel to it (due to mesenteric tethering).

 

Statement 4. Colon cancer risk can be decreased by metformin: Correct. Several studies show that metformin reduces colon cancer risk in diabetics by improving insulin sensitivity and reducing hyperinsulinemia (which is a growth-promoting factor for colonic epithelium).

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 2. M3 midline hernia refers to epigastric hernia: Incorrect. According to the European Hernia Society classification, M3 = umbilical hernia. Epigastric hernia corresponds to M2.

questions.text: A child sustained a fracture after a fall. The post-op x-ray is shown below. The fracture will heal by which mechanism?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Primary healing

 

The X-ray reveals a long bone fracture treated with rigid plating, bringing fracture ends into close contact and providing absolute stability. This setup allows the bone to heal through primary healing (direct bone healing), which involves remodelling of the Haversian systems across the fracture plane without visible callus formation. Cutting cones traverse the fracture line and new bone is laid down directly, provided movement at the fracture site is minimal.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Creeping substitution: Refers to the process of bone graft remodelling, not the mechanism of fracture healing itself.
 

Option B. Intramembranous ossification: Characterizes embryonic bone formation or some bone graft healing, not typical for direct fracture healing with rigid fixation.
 

Option D. Secondary healing: Involves callus formation and endochondral ossification, usually seen in fractures treated conservatively or with less rigid fixation.

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements:

 

  1. The most common complication of an untreated radial head dislocation is the cubitus valgus deformity at the elbow. 
  2. Seek kebab surgery / Sofield Miller Osteotomy is performed for Achondroplasia 
  3. Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP) is elevated in osteoporosis
  4. Posterior tibialis tendon is palpable behind the medial malleolus during inversion of the foot
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 3, 4

 

Statement 1. The most common complication of an untreated radial head dislocation is the cubitus valgus deformity at the elbow: Radial head dislocation untreated leads to cubitus valgus deformity.

 

Statement 3. Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP) is elevated in osteoporosis: Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP), a marker of osteoclast activity, is elevated in osteoporosis due to increased bone resorption.

 

Statement 4. Posterior tibialis tendon is palpable behind the medial malleolus during inversion of the foot: Posterior tibialis tendon is palpable behind the medial malleolus during foot inversion.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 2. Seek kebab surgery / Sofield Miller Osteotomy is performed for Achondroplasia: Sheffield or Sofield-Miller osteotomy is used for bowed long bones in osteogenesis imperfecta[shown below], not achondroplasia.

questions.text: A 1-month-old girl is brought to the OPD for a routine newborn examination.  Physical examination is shown below. When supine with the knees flexed, the left knee appears to be inferior to the right knee. Skin examination shows a nonblanching, blue-grey macule with indefinite borders over the sacrum. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ultrasound of hips 

 

The image and clinical scenario show asymmetric thigh folds and a left knee that is lower than the right when knees are flexed (Galeazzi sign), consistent with developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH). In infants under 6 months, the most appropriate next step is ultrasound of the hips to assess hip joint integrity and positioning, because cartilage is not yet ossified and X-rays are less sensitive at this age.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Reassurance: Not appropriate due to signs suggestive of hip dysplasia requiring prompt investigation and intervention.
 

Option B. Skeletal survey: Indicated only if child abuse or metabolic bone disease is suspected, not in isolated DDH findings.
 

Option D. X-ray of hips: Not useful in infants under 6 months because femoral head and acetabulum are mostly cartilaginous at this age.

questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hematemesis 

 

Reynold’s pentad is seen in severe acute suppurative cholangitis and includes:

 

  1. Charcot’s triad – fever, jaundice, right upper quadrant pain
  2. PENTAD: TRIAD + Hypotension (shock) + Altered mental status (confusion)

 

Hematemesis is not a feature; it suggests upper gastrointestinal bleeding (e.g., varices, peptic ulcer).

questions.text: What other finding would be expected in this 25-year-old male with abnormal pelvis MRI?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acute painful red eye

 

This MRI image demonstrates bilateral sacroiliitis, a hallmark of ankylosing spondylitis, particularly in young men. Ankylosing spondylitis is frequently associated with extra-articular manifestations, most notably acute anterior uveitis, which presents as an acute painful red eye with photophobia and blurred vision. The connection is because both sacroiliitis and uveitis are seronegative spondyloarthropathy features and often co-exist in affected patients. Recognizing the ocular involvement is crucial in evaluating systemic disease activity and providing holistic management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Elevated RF: Rheumatoid factor (RF) is typically negative in ankylosing spondylitis and other seronegative spondyloarthropathies. The absence of RF helps differentiate it from rheumatoid arthritis, making this finding unlikely.

 

Option C. Atlanto-axial dislocation: Atlanto-axial dislocation is classically seen in advanced rheumatoid arthritis or juvenile idiopathic arthritis, not in ankylosing spondylitis. Although cervical spine involvement (like fusion) is seen later in AS, dislocation is rare.

 

Option D. IV disc calcification: Intervertebral disc calcification is usually associated with degenerative spinal diseases or metabolic conditions, not with ankylosing spondylitis or sacroiliitis. AS typically causes syndesmophyte formation and spinal ankylosis  but not disc calcification

questions.text: A 64-year-old man with a history of coronary artery disease undergoes coronary artery bypass surgery. His postoperative course is complicated by hypotension, which is treated successfully with intravenous fluids; however, a few hours later, he experiences severe abdominal pain followed by bloody diarrhea.  Abdominal examination shows normal bowel sounds, with no significant guarding or focal tenderness. The venous lactic acid level is elevated.  An abdominal CT scan is ordered which shows edema at the anastomotic bridging between the right and left terminal branches of the ascending left colic artery. What is this point referred to as?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Griffith point

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents with a thyroid nodule. Serum TSH is normal. Ultrasound of her thyroid reveals a 1.5-cm hypoechoic nodule in the right thyroid lobe with irregular margins, internal microcalcifications, and internal vascularity. FNAC is performed which is reported as Thy3 Bethesda grade. Which of the following is the next most appropriate step in management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hemi-thyroidectomy 

 

Thy3 / Bethesda III corresponds to follicular lesion of undetermined significance or follicular neoplasm, with a 10–30% risk of malignancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Repeat FNAC: May be considered in some Thy3 nodules, but suspicious ultrasound features and patient preference usually favor diagnostic surgery.

 

Option B. MRI of the neck: Not indicated for evaluation of thyroid nodules; it is reserved for large, invasive, or retrosternal masses or for staging.

 

Option D. RAIU scan: Useful only if TSH is suppressed to differentiate “hot” vs “cold” nodules; in euthyroid patients, a cold nodule on RAIU may indicate higher malignancy risk, but ultrasound + FNAC already guides management here.

questions.text: Identify the ethmoidal cells shown in the CT:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Agger nasi

 

  • The CT scan shows air cells located anterior and superior to the nasolacrimal duct, marked by arrows.
  • These are Agger nasi cells, which are the most anterior ethmoidal air cells.
  • They are located just anterior to the attachment of the middle turbinate and are important surgically, as they form the anterior boundary of the frontal recess.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bulla ethmoidalis: 

 

  • The largest and most constant anterior ethmoidal cell.
  • Lies posterior to the uncinate process and forms part of the lateral nasal wall.

 

 

Option B. Concha bullosa:

 

  • Pneumatization of the middle turbinate itself.
  • Seen as an air-filled cavity inside the turbinate, not as anterior ethmoid cells.

 

 

Option D. Haller cell:

 

  • Infraorbital ethmoid air cells, located along the floor of the orbit near the maxillary sinus roof.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with dizziness and involuntary eye movements. Examination reveals non-fatiguable nystagmus that changes direction with gaze and is not suppressed by visual fixation. There are no significant auditory symptoms. What is the most likely cause of his nystagmus?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Brainstem stroke

 

This patient has features of central vertigo rather than peripheral.

 

  • Non-fatiguable nystagmus → Central (peripheral nystagmus fatigues with repeated testing, eg. in BPPV).
  • Direction-changing with gaze → Central (peripheral is unidirectional).
  • Not suppressed by visual fixation → Central (peripheral nystagmus decreases when patient fixates).
  • No auditory symptoms → Suggests it is not an inner ear (peripheral) disorder, which usually has hearing loss, tinnitus, or ear fullness.

 

Thus, the most likely cause = brainstem stroke (central vestibular lesion).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV):

 

  • Vertigo triggered by positional changes, lasts seconds.
  • Nystagmus is fatiguable, unidirectional, suppressed by fixation.
  • Not fitting here.

 

Option B. Vestibular neuritis:

 

  • Sudden severe vertigo without hearing loss.
  • Nystagmus is unidirectional and suppressed by fixation.
  • Not direction-changing.

 

Option D. Ménière’s disease:

 

  • Triad: episodic vertigo, fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus.
  • Always has auditory symptoms, absent here.

choices.text: Bacteria that form biofilms are usually metabolically more active

questions.text: Which of the following statement is false about biofilms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bacteria that form biofilms are usually metabolically more active

 

  • Biofilms are structured communities of bacteria enclosed in a self-produced glycocalyx (extracellular polysaccharide matrix) and attached to surfaces (prosthetic devices, catheters, teeth, mucosa, etc).

 

Within biofilms:

 

  • Bacteria are usually in a low metabolic state → making them more resistant to antibiotics and host defenses.
  • Biofilms use quorum sensing (cell-to-cell signaling via autoinducers) to coordinate growth, virulence, and detachment.
  • They are responsible for chronic and prosthetic infections (eg, Staphylococcus epidermidis in prosthetic valves/catheters, Pseudomonas in CF lungs, dental plaque).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Responsible for prosthetic infections: True.

 

  • Biofilms are notorious in prosthetic device–related infections (eg, prosthetic heart valves, joint replacements, central venous catheters, urinary catheters, intrauterine devices).
  • Within biofilms, bacteria are resistant to antibiotics and immune responses, leading to chronic, relapsing infections that often require removal of the device.
  • Example organisms:
    • Staphylococcus epidermidis → prosthetic valve endocarditis.
    • Pseudomonas aeruginosa → biofilms in cystic fibrosis lungs and on catheters.

 

Option C. Glycocalyx enclosed bacteria: True.

 

  • Biofilm bacteria are embedded in a self-produced extracellular polymeric substance (EPS), often called glycocalyx.
  • This glycocalyx:
    • Protects bacteria from antibiotics, antibodies, and phagocytosis.
    • Provides structural stability and nutrient exchange.
  • Classic example: Streptococcus mutans in dental plaque, producing a glycocalyx from sucrose.

 

Option D. Associated with quorum sensing: True.

 

  • Quorum sensing is the mechanism bacteria use to “talk” to each other via autoinducers (chemical signals).
  • Once a threshold bacterial density is reached, coordinated gene expression occurs → promoting biofilm formation, virulence factor production, and dispersal.
  • Examples:
    • Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses quorum sensing to regulate biofilm thickness and toxin production.
    • Vibrio fischeri uses quorum sensing for bioluminescence (classic model system).

questions.text: A patient presented with a prolonged fever of unknown origin (PUO), raising suspicion of brucellosis. To confirm the diagnosis, various dilutions of the patient's serum sample are prepared for a standard agglutination test. The outcome is as follows: Agglutination is observed at serum dilutions of 1:20 and 1:40, while no agglutination occurs at dilutions of 1:80 and 1:160. What factor is accountable for the lack of agglutination in the last two dilutions?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Antigen excess

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient complains of severe pain in his right ear associated with high-grade fever and profuse ear discharge. Clinical examination reveals mastoid tenderness and perforation of the tympanic membrane. If this infection were to burst out through the medial aspect of the tip of the mastoid, which of the following conditions would ensue?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bezold abscess

 

  • Bezold’s abscess:
    • Occurs when pus from mastoiditis escapes through the medial aspect of mastoid tip into the sternocleidomastoid sheath.
    • Presents as deep neck abscess with neck swelling, fever, and pain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pre-auricular abscess: Localized abscess in front of the ear, not related to mastoid tip.

 

Option C. Luc abscess: Subperiosteal abscess in children, due to infection breaking through outer cortex of mastoid → swelling above ear, without bone destruction.

 

Option D. Citelli’s abscess: Pus spreads posteriorly through mastoid emissary vein → occipital/retroauricular swelling.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding Bartter's syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Autosomal dominant disorder 

 

  • True statements:
    • A. Hypokalaemia and metabolic alkalosis: due to increased distal sodium delivery → enhanced K⁺ and H⁺ secretion.
    • B. Indomethacin may be used for treatment: because excess renal prostaglandins worsen salt wasting → NSAIDs help.
    • C. Associated with sensorineural deafness: especially in Bartter type IV (BSND gene mutation).

 

  • False statement:
    • D. Autosomal dominant disorder → Most forms of Bartter’s syndrome are autosomal recessive.
