questions.text: Arrange in sequence the cyclins at different stages of the cell cycle starting from the G1 phase.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cyclin D- Cyclin E- Cyclin A- Cyclin B 

 

  • Cyclin D: G1 phase, drives progression through G1.
  • Cyclin E: G1/S transition, initiates DNA replication.
  • Cyclin A: S phase and G2, promotes DNA synthesis and prepares for mitosis.
  • Cyclin B: M phase, required for entry into mitosis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents with a 3-month history of weight loss, fever, and a persistent cough. Imaging of the chest reveals bilateral apical opacities with cavitation. A lung biopsy is performed, which is shown below. Which of the following cell surface markers is most specific for the cells predominantly found surrounding the necrotic tissue?
questions.solution: Ans. C) CD14

questions.text:
Among the following, which cells have both MHC class I and MHC class II? 

 

  1. NK cells
  2. B-lymphocytes
  3. Dendritic cells
  4. Platelets
  5. RBC
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2, 3

 

  • B-lymphocytes: Express MHC I and II, present antigens to helper T-cells.
  • Dendritic cells: Professional antigen-presenting cells expressing both MHC I and II.

 

Incorrect options:

 

  • 1. NK cells: Express MHC I but not MHC II.
  • 4. Platelets: Express MHC I only, no MHC II.
  • 5. RBC: Lack both MHC I and II.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is hospitalized due to worsening confusion and vomiting of blood for the past 2 days. Medical history is notable for irritability and declining school performance over the past year. He is oriented to person but disoriented to time and place. During hospitalization, the patient rapidly deteriorates and passes away. Autopsy examination reveals Nodular liver, Splenomegaly, Basal ganglia atrophy with increased copper content. The most likely cause of this patient’s condition is an abnormality in which of the following physiologic processes?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Biliary copper excretion

 

  • This is Wilson disease, a genetic disorder of ATP7B gene → defective copper excretion into bile → copper accumulation in liver, brain, and basal ganglia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Serum copper transporter defect: Refers to ceruloplasmin; not the primary problem.

 

Option C. Increased intestinal absorption: Normal in Wilson disease.

 

Option D. Decreased urinary excretion: Actually, urinary copper is elevated in Wilson disease.

questions.text: A 75-year-old hypertensive male patient presents with dizziness and palpitations. On examination, his pulse rate is 110 per minute with an irregularly irregular rhythm. His ECG is given below. He does not have a history of diabetes, congestive heart failure, cerebrovascular disease.  What is his CHA2DS2-VASc score?
questions.solution: Ans. C) 3

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true of the baroreceptor reflex pathway?

 

  1. Rostral ventrolateral medulla (RVLM) is inhibited by CVLM. 
  2. Caudal ventrolateral medulla (CVLM) releases GABA.
  3. Nucleus tractus solitarius (NTS) releases GABA.
  4. Stretch receptors are stimulated by increased blood pressure
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 4

 

In the baroreceptor reflex pathway:

 

1. The rostral ventrolateral medulla (RVLM), which drives sympathetic outflow, is inhibited by the caudal ventrolateral medulla (CVLM) during increased blood pressure to reduce sympathetic tone.

 

2. The CVLM releases GABA, an inhibitory neurotransmitter that suppresses the RVLM.

 

4. Stretch receptors (baroreceptors) are stimulated by increased blood pressure.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

3. The nucleus tractus solitarius (NTS) primarily receives afferent input from baroreceptors and is primarily excitatory, not generally releasing GABA.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not caused by Trinucleotide repeat mutations involving coding regions?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Myotonic dystrophy

 

Myotonic dystrophy is caused by CTG repeat expansion in the 3′ untranslated region (non-coding region) of the DMPK gene.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. Spinocerebellar ataxia: Caused by CAG repeat expansions in coding regions.

 

Option C. Huntington disease: Caused by CAG repeats in the coding region of the HTT gene.

 

Option D. Kennedy disease: Caused by CAG repeats in the coding region of the androgen receptor gene.
